answers.answer: The answer to your questions is maybe.  Nodules in the thyroid can be associated with both hyperthyroidism (overactive thyroid) and hypothyroidism (underactive thyroid).  From the symptoms you described it sounds like you might be hypo but I can't be sure (generally when you are hyper it's easy to lose weight).  If you are already underactive then removing the one side of your thyroid may or may not affect your hormone levels.  In some people who have part of their thyroid removed the other half that remains steps up to the plate & is able to make enough hormone to compensate.  In others, they need to go on synthroid to replace the hormone that's not being made.  If you are already hypo it may be due to an autoimmune disease like Hashimoto's (your immune system is overactive & attacks your body and in this case the thyroid) so the level of thyroid hormone in your body could be related to the disease and not necessarily the nodule itself.  If you don't have an endocrinologist I would suggest getting one and making sure that they are very knowledgable about thyroids - many endos focus mainly on diabetes.  What your levels will do and what treatment you will need afterwards will depend on whether you are hypo or hyper and what the remaining part of your thyroid does in terms of thyroid hormone production.  I hope this helps you some.Rayne
